title: Domain 3.3: Given a scenario, use best practice procedures for malware removal.

  • Watch for pop-ups, sluggishness, or security tools being disabled.
  • Use Task Manager and antivirus logs to check for unusual processes.

2. ğŸ›‘ Quarantine Infected Systems

  • Disconnect from network (Wi-Fi/Ethernet) immediately.
  • Physically isolate or use endpoint tools to contain the threat.

3. ğŸš« Disable System Restore in Windows

  • Prevents reinfection from restore points.
  • Re-enable it after the system is clean.

4. ğŸ§½ Remediate Infected Systems

  • a. Update Anti-malware Software: Ensure virus definitions are current.
  • b. Scanning and Removal Techniques:
    • Use Safe Mode for scanning.
    • Use bootable AV tools if needed.
    • Perform a full scan to eliminate threats.

5. ğŸ“… Schedule Scans and Run Updates

  • Set up automatic scans and software updates.
  • Keep the OS and applications patched to close vulnerabilities.

6. ğŸ—‚ï¸ Enable System Restore and Create a Restore Point

  • Turn System Restore back on once the system is clean.
  • Create a restore point for future rollbacks.

7. ğŸ§  Educate the End User

  • Teach safe email/web practices and the importance of updates.
  • Empower users to recognize phishing and suspicious behavior.
